author: By Judson Jones and Claire Fahy
title: Central Park Goes 653 Days Without an Inch of Snow
description: The park hasn’t recorded a major snowfall since Feb. 13, 2022.
content: Remember when it used to snow in New York City?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Ample Hills Founders Are Out of the Business Again
description: A Brooklyn couple aimed to revive their ice cream company after it collapsed. Now their new investors have fired them.
content: Despite what the Hallmark Channel tells us at this time of year, fairy-tale endings don’t always stick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Kansans Hated Their New License Plate. Now They’ll Vote on a Replacement.
description: For six days, politicians from both sides of the aisle and other Kansans expressed their distaste for what was supposed to have been the state’s new license plate.
content: Last week, Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas revealed a new license plate design for the state’s motor vehicles. But after nearly a week of bipartisan criticism from constituents and politicians alike, she has yielded to dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: From $4 Thrift-Store Find to $191,000 Sale, Back to $4
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 29, 2023.
content: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Pope Francis Tries to Settle Accounts
description: Punishing conservatives, reining in progressives.
content: For years now, Pope Francis’ governance of the Roman Catholic Church has been seemingly designed to drive the church’s conservative and liberal wings ever further apart. Thus the persistent question hanging over his pontificate: How will he hold this thing together?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: A Vintage Shop to the Stars Holds Its Own Against New Rivals
description: Thirty years after starting What Goes Around Comes Around, Gerard Maione and Seth Weisser are still on the hunt for lost classics from Hermès, Chanel and Levi’s.
content: On a recent afternoon in SoHo, Seth Weisser and Gerard Maione were checking in on their shop, What Goes Around Comes Around, a luxury vintage boutique on West Broadway that has long been a downtown destination for stylists and celebrities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Anne Brown
title: Watch ‘Sea Fireflies’ Make Underwater Fireworks as They Seek Mates
description: Tiny crustaceans the size of sand grains sneeze up packets of glowing mucus to impress potential partners.
content: In 2017, two evolutionary biologists snorkeling off Panama’s coast made a dazzling discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: As Congress Weighs Aid to Israel, Some Democrats Want Strings Attached
description: Democrats are clashing with each other and the Biden administration over whether to attach conditions, including measures to avoid civilian casualties, to security assistance.
content: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Don’t Be Afraid of the iPhone’s NameDrop Feature, Experts Say
description: Police departments have issued warnings about a new Apple setting that lets users exchange contact information by bringing their devices together. Tech experts say the fears are overblown.
content: Police departments from New Jersey to California have been sounding the alarm in recent days about NameDrop, a new feature of the Apple iPhone’s latest operating system that allows users to wirelessly exchange contact information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark A. Graber
title: Donald Trump and the Jefferson Davis Problem
description: Why Section 3 of the 14th Amendment was added to the Constitution and remains relevant.
content: State courts in Colorado, Michigan, Minnesota and elsewhere have so far declined to rule in favor of challenges asserting that Donald Trump should be disqualified from holding the presidency again under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. (Cases in Michigan and Colorado have been appealed.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Treading an Endless Road That Connects to the Past
description: Okwui Okpokwasili and Peter Born’s hybrid show, “Adaku, Part 1,” about a precolonial African village, mixes dance theater, song and drama.
content: Before it begins, they are already on the move — a cluster of women, walking in a circle. And for nearly the entire 75 minutes of “Adaku, Part 1: The Road Opens” they continue walking, to a drumbeat that almost never ceases. The road they are on isn’t ordinary. It’s metaphorical, the one the connects the past to the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Taylor Swift Beats Out Bad Bunny in 2023’s Spotify Wrapped
description: The “Midnights” singer ended Bad Bunny’s three-year reign as the music platform’s most-streamed star.
content: Don’t you just love the holiday season? Diwali. Thanksgiving. Hanukkah. Christmas. And, uh, Spotify Wrapped Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: The Dilemmas of a Petrostate Preparing to Host a Climate Summit
description: Climate activists have balked at the fact that a leading oil producer, the United Arab Emirates, is hosting this year’s U.N. climate talks. But Emirati officials say they, too, are grappling with hard questions.
content: The choice of a leading oil producer, the United Arab Emirates, to host this year’s U.N. climate talks has angered environmental activists. But for the Emirates and other countries both highly dependent on oil and deeply vulnerable to rising temperatures, grappling with climate change is an urgent dilemma for them, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Google Agrees to Pay Canadian Media for Using Their Content
description: The Canadian government reached a deal with Google before a new law compelling tech giants to compensate news organizations comes into effect late next month.
content: Canada’s standoff with the technology giants Google and Meta over their use of domestic news content eased on one front, as the federal government announced Wednesday that it had reached a deal with Google to compensate publishers in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Jezebel to Be Resurrected by Paste Magazine
description: The pioneering feminist website is being sold to Paste by G/O Media, which had shut down the site this month.
content: Jezebel, the famed feminist website, is set to return less than a month after it was shuttered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Daisaku Ikeda, Who Led Influential Japanese Buddhist Group, Dies at 95
description: He grew Soka Gakkai International’s following over two decades and helped create a coalition partner for the country’s dominant Liberal Democratic Party.
content: Daisaku Ikeda, the president of Soka Gakkai International, the global arm of a Buddhist movement in Japan that spawned an influential political partner to the country’s governing party, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Tokyo. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Jillian Weinberger
title: America Has a Homelessness Problem. Houston Has a Solution.
description: Nicholas Kristof travels to the city for a firsthand look.
content: Like many American cities, Houston had a longstanding problem with homelessness. But over the past 12 years, the city has managed to cut homelessness by more than 60 percent. In this audio essay, the columnist Nicholas Kristof follows Houston outreach workers to an encampment to see the city’s strategy in action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Yiwen Lu
title: G.M. to Cut Spending on Cruise Self-Driving Unit
description: General Motors will “substantially lower spending” on autonomous vehicle efforts in 2024 after accidents with its self-driving taxis in San Francisco.
content: General Motors is slowing the expansion of its Cruise automated driving division and significantly cutting spending at the unit after suspending operations in response to growing safety concerns about its driverless cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 5, Episode 3 Recap: Preparing for a Blood Bath
description: Dot’s pursuers seem to be on the verge of being pursued themselves.
content: The Coen brothers filmography is speckled with a specific type of abstract character, a dark and indomitable force of nature who isn’t quite human and operates on a code that is known only to him. Think Leonard Smalls (Randall “Tex” Cobb) in “Raising Arizona,” a mercenary biker who seems manifested from a nightmare, or Charlie Meadows (John Goodman) in “Barton Fink,” a gregarious insurance man who presents himself as “the common man” but reveals a second identity that is exceptionally uncommon. Then there’s the gun-for-hire Anton Chigurh (Javier Bardem) in “No Country for Old Men,” who asks his victims to “flip a coin,” but always seems in control of their fate regardless. He may represent Death itself, but his agenda has an odd rigor and consistency to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
title: India Ignored Repeated Warnings Before Tunnel Trapped 41 Men
description: Environmentalists argued that a road project was destabilizing the fragile Himalayan landscape. The government maneuvered to continue it.
content: As the trapped workers came out of the under-construction road tunnel after 17 days, the happy end to a rescue effort that had riveted India set off celebrations across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Matter of Debate
description: Ruth Bloomfield Margolin opts for wit.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: An Endorsement for Nikki Haley, and More
description: Plus, Hamas releases 12 more hostages, the true cost of avocados and Google says it will start purging accounts.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How Did San Francisco Become the City in a ‘Doom Loop’?
description: A conversation with Jesse Barron, who wrote about a high-profile attack in San Francisco and about worries over the city’s future.
content: Perhaps you remember when two high-profile crimes in San Francisco this spring put the city’s woes in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Snowplow Parents Are Ruining Online Grading
description: Hyperchecking is robbing students of opportunities to develop autonomy.
content: During the 2011-12 school year, Roxanne Greitz Miller was a professor-in-residence at a California middle school that had just started using an online grade book app that allowed parents and students to see students’ grades as soon as they were posted. I recently spoke to Miller, who is now the dean of the College of Educational Studies at Chapman University, and she said it was clear to her almost immediately that this technology was “game changing” for parents, teachers and students — and not in a good way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: In a Shaky Oil Market, OPEC Has Bitter Decisions to Make
description: Anticipating a drop in demand for 2024, major producers, led by Saudi Arabia, are trying to reduce supply.
content: These are tricky times for the world’s major oil producers: Prices are lower, the health of the global economy is uncertain, and, even as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries tries to cut output, supplies from other producers, notably the United States, are growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Julian E. Barnes and Ian Austen
title: U.S. Says Indian Official Directed Assassination Plot in New York
description: A Manhattan indictment says the agent orchestrated an unsuccessful plot against a Sikh separatist, a plan linked to a killing in Canada.
content: It was described as a New York hit job with international implications: an audacious assassination plot against a Sikh separatist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What to Expect at Today’s DealBook Summit
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, Elon Musk, Bob Iger, Jamie Dimon and Tsai Ing-wen, the president of Taiwan, are among the big names speaking.
content: On Wednesday, DealBook will be live and in person at our annual summit in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: A Race to Extend the Gaza Truce
description: Plus the U.S. charges an Indian man in an assassination plot.
content: Top officials from Qatar, Egypt and the U.S. were pushing to lock in another extension of the cease-fire in Gaza between Israel and Hamas, which is set to expire today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Hunter College Reschedules Screening of Film Critical of Israel
description: Hunter’s cancellation of a screening of the documentary “Israelism” had caused an outcry among faculty members and students, who said it was a violation of academic freedom.
content: Hunter College has agreed to reschedule a screening of a documentary critical of Israel, following an outcry from faculty members and students who claimed that the administration’s earlier decision to cancel it violated academic freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Dead Relative May Have Been a Racist Gangster. How Can I Help His Kids?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to support family amid troubling circumstances.
content: Recently a relative from a distant state was shot and killed in what the authorities believe was a gang-related dispute, leaving behind a spouse and young children. In the aftermath, friends and relatives of the family used a GoFundMe campaign to help with expenses. Photos have circulated on social media before and since that show my relative and their spouse and friends wearing clothing with the insignia of the gang, which is well known. Over the years, according to the F.B.I. and news reports, the gang has been tied to murders, shootings, Nazi symbolism, illegal drug trafficking and running an escort service. Posts by my relative’s spouse suggest that they are proud to be associated with the gang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Remy Tumin
title: Elon Musk Uses a Crude Insult to Slam Advertisers for Pulling Back From X.
description: Although Mr. Musk acknowledged that an extended boycott could bankrupt X, he suggested that the public would blame the brands rather than him for its collapse.
content: Elon Musk hit out at brands that have pulled their advertising from X after he endorsed an antisemitic conspiracy theory on the social media platform.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 29, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about daily life in Gaza misspelled the name of a man trying to find water for his family. He is Nazmi Mwafi, not Namzi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why Some New Yorkers May Soon Feel the Effect of Ocean Winds
description: The wind-power industry may be facing a crisis, but huge turbines going up off Long Island could be producing electricity for homes before 2023 ends.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at what a wind farm in the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island could soon mean for consumers who use electricity. We’ll also find out the origins of this year’s Rockefeller Center Christmas tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Maria Callas Was Opera’s Defining Diva. She Still Is.
description: Callas would have turned 100 on Dec. 2. She and her flash of a career remain beacons of artistic integrity and profundity.
content: Her voice is the shadow that remains after shock, after anger: the sound of a woman realizing she has nothing left to live for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: A Subway Ride at the Paris Olympics Could Cost You Almost Double
description: Citing the price tag of ramped-up service for the Games, the regional transit authority is planning big increases aimed at visitors from July 20 to Sept. 8.
content: With nearly 10 million people expected to throng the streets of Paris during the Olympics this summer, visitors already knew getting around the city would be a challenge. But now it will probably be a lot more expensive, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Read Rosalynn Carter’s full obituary.
description: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Nov. 19 in Plains, Ga. She was 96.
content: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Nov. 19 in Plains, Ga. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markham Heid
title: The Truth About Sleep Trackers
description: Their technology is impressive, but imperfect. We asked experts whether they can really help you get a better night’s rest.
content: Shawn McCall, 48, a personal trainer in Waterford, Mich., started tracking his sleep almost six years ago. Mr. McCall said that his Oura Ring — a sleek titanium device that he wears on his ring finger — has revealed how the choices he makes during his waking hours affect his sleep at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple Is Doing Its Part to End Green Bubble Shaming. It’s Our Turn.
description: While texting technology will soon get better, the “blue versus green bubble” disparity is far from over.
content: For more than a decade, smartphone users everywhere have faced a major problem in how we communicate: the “green versus blue bubble” disparity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Maria Cramer
title: 2 Shot on Subway Train in Brooklyn During Evening Rush, Police Say
description: The victims, a teenager and a man in his 40s, sustained minor injuries after a gunman opened fire on a C train, the police said.
content: A gunman shot a 17-year-old boy and a man in his 40s inside a moving subway car as it approached a station in Brooklyn’s Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood during the evening rush hour on Tuesday, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Longer This Cake Soaks, the Better It Is
description: The faint bitterness of Thai tea gets absorbed into tres leches, checking the sweetness, so it’s just enough.
content: Now this is a diner, where the pancakes puff into burnished domes and the syrup-to-pancake ratio is 1 to 1. (“The correct and nonnegotiable ratio,” the writer and editor Rohan Kamicheril says.) Sam Yoo, the chef and owner, called it Golden Diner when he opened it in 2019, in a corner of Chinatown where the Manhattan Bridge hulks at the end of the street. The tabletops are Formica, the windows are draped in lace and the time is always breakfast, whatever’s on the plate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Star With Six Planets That Orbit Perfectly in Sync
description: One hundred light years away, a handful of planets are circling a star in the same configuration as when they formed.
content: Astronomers have discovered six planets orbiting a bright star in perfect resonance. The star system, 100 light-years from Earth, was described on Wednesday in a paper published in the journal Nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Simple, Lemony Pasta for Catching Your Breath
description: With braised white beans and juicy marinated cherry tomatoes, it’s the sort of vegetarian dinner I crave this time of year.
content: This year I’ve designated the week after Thanksgiving as my between-feasts reset. The last of the turkey leftovers have been devoured, but all that December cookie making has yet to begin, so it’s a fine time to clean out the fridge, reorganize the pantry and focus on lighter meals loaded with wholesome vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Cozy One-Pot Chicken for a Fuss-Free Holiday
description: With carrots, sweet potatoes and dates, this braise is a colorful main course for your Hanukkah table.
content: The Yiddish word tsimmes, or tzimmes, means to make a big fuss over something. It’s also the name of an Ashkenazi dish of sweet potatoes, carrots, dried fruit and sometimes flanken or brisket, traditionally served at Jewish holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Jen Poyant, Corey Schreppel, Sophia Lanman, Marion Lozano, Carole Sabouraud and Dan Powell
title: Our 34-Year Age Gap Didn’t Matter, Until It Did
description: Sonja Falck was happily married to a man 34 years her senior. When their age gap started to test their bond, they had to change their relationship in order to save it.
content: Sonja Falck was immediately attracted to Colin, the professor who was renting her a room. He was intellectual and lively, with bright eyes that drew her in. It was only after they were already dating that Sonja found out Colin’s age: He was 34 years older than her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: This Seed Season, Consider a Catalog That Takes a Different Approach
description: At Turtle Tree Seed, adults with developmental differences work “side by side” with other staff to produce seed that’s more artisanal than agribusiness.
content: It takes a village, not a threshing machine, to complete the harvest of pounds of watermelon seeds that will fill the simple, white packets sold by Turtle Tree Seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Michael Crowley
title: NATO Ministers Vow to Maintain Support for Ukraine
description: Amid questions over Western resolve, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other diplomats stressed their commitment to Kyiv’s bid to join the alliance.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and top Western diplomats vowed on Wednesday to sustain support for Ukraine and its bid to join NATO despite dwindling military supplies and competing crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Britain Says Bye-Bye to Its Only Pandas as They’ll Soon Depart for China
description: The playful, waddling bears charmed millions of people at the Edinburgh Zoo of the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland.
content: Britain’s only two pandas will soon be returned to China, officials said, in a send-off that has dispirited fans of the playful, waddling bears and signals what appears to be the end, at least for now, of panda diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.5 Million Homes in California and Arizona
description: A midcentury-modern house in Long Beach and a renovated 1995 home in Scottsdale.
content: This home was designed by Lloyd Wright, Frank Lloyd Wright’s son, who worked extensively in Southern California, on his projects of his own, like Wayfarers Chapel in Rancho Palos Verdes, as well as buildings associated with his father. The sellers have updated the house with a new HVAC system, new windows and new plumbing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Schumer Condemns Antisemitism, Warning the Left Against Abetting It
description: The majority leader and highest-ranking Jewish official in the country cautioned progressives and young people against unwittingly embracing bigotry in the name of social justice.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, on Wednesday warned that some liberals and young people were “unknowingly aiding and abetting” antisemitism in the name of social justice, fueling a dangerous rise in bigotry against Jews amid Israel’s war against Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Wolverines Get Protection in the Lower 48 States
description: Officials will add the predators, threatened by climate change and habitat loss in much of the United States, to the Endangered Species List.
content: Wolverines in the contiguous United States are threatened by climate change and habitat fragmentation and will be listed under the Endangered Species Act, the federal government announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeria Luiselli
title: A Masterpiece That Inspired Gabriel García Márquez to Write His Own
description: For decades, Juan Rulfo’s novel, “Pedro Páramo,” has cast an uncanny spell on writers. A new translation may bring it broader appeal.
content: Readers of Latin American literature may have heard one of the many versions of this story:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
title: U.S. Debates How Much to Sever Electric Car Industry’s Ties to China
description: Some firms argue that a law aimed at popularizing electric vehicles risks turning the United States into an assembly shop for Chinese-made technology.
content: The Biden administration has been trying to jump-start the domestic supply chain for electric vehicles so cleaner cars can be made in the United States. But the experience of one Texas company, whose plans to help make an all-American electric vehicle were upended by China, highlights the stakes involved as the administration finalizes rules governing the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Innovative Cancer Treatment May Sometimes Cause Cancer, F.D.A. Says
description: The agency is looking into reports that some patients developed new blood cancers after receiving CAR-T treatments.
content: A lifesaving cancer treatment may itself cause cancers, the Food and Drug Administration reported on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Jenna Russell
title: For Palestinian Students Shot in Vermont, a Collision of Two Worlds
description: “In the West Bank we’re not safe,” one injured student said, “and as a Palestinian American, I’m not safe in America because of people like this that might come out.”
content: In many ways, the three young men who were shot as they ambled down a sidewalk last Saturday in Burlington, Vt., were like any other longtime friends reuniting on a leisurely Thanksgiving weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: The truce between Israel and Hamas held for another day.
description: Hours after Hamas and Israel completed the fifth exchange of hostages and prisoners, their fragile truce continued into Wednesday, allowing for more people to be released on both sides, as global leaders called for a longer pause in fighting.
content: Hours after Hamas and Israel completed the fifth exchange of hostages and prisoners, their fragile truce continued into Wednesday, allowing for more people to be released on both sides, as global leaders called for a longer pause in fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope’s Critics Feel the Sting After His Patience Runs Out
description: Vatican observers see a leader more willing to crack down on those seeking to derail his agenda for the Roman Catholic Church.
content: As Pope Francis smiled warmly at the circus performers spinning and flipping in front of him at his weekly general audience in the Vatican on Wednesday, he looked every bit the grandfatherly figure who has for the last decade sought to make the church a kinder, gentler and more inclusive place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Wary of In-House S.E.C. Tribunals
description: The justices heard arguments over whether the Constitution allows the agency to pursue enforcement actions before its own judges instead of in federal courts.
content: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed receptive on Wednesday to an attack on one of the primary ways the Securities and Exchange Commission enforces laws against securities fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Citi Is Sued Over Sex Abuse. Before 2022, It Would Have Been a Secret.
description: Ardith Lindsey, a managing director, is accusing the bank of tolerating a culture in which managers sexually harassed her.
content: A female employee of Citigroup recently sued the bank, accusing its leadership of tolerating a work culture in which she was sexually harassed and abused by male executives, in a high-profile application of a 2022 federal law that nullified forced arbitration for such cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: We Spied on Our Teenage Daughter With a Hidden Camera. Now What Do We Do?
description: Parents who installed a camera in the eye of their daughter’s stuffed bear ask how — and whether — to come clean about their surveillance now that she has left for college.
content: A few years ago, we gave our daughter, now 18, a stuffed bear for her birthday. At the time, we had recently discovered she had a boyfriend whom she was hiding from us. It was quite a shock. We wanted to be able to keep a closer eye on what she was doing without breaking her trust, so we installed a hidden camera inside the eye of the stuffed bear. Our daughter is now in college, and we overheard her telling her roommate how grateful she was for our trust in her and our support. We have been racked with guilt ever since. How can we tell our daughter about the camera without destroying our relationship with her? Should we tell her at all?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Mistress America,’ ‘Tramps’ and More Streaming Gems
description: A pair of charming Gotham-based character comedies are among the highlights of this month’s under-the-radar streaming recommendations.
content: “Barbie” is the current commercial and critical triumph of the screenwriting (and real-life) partners Greta Gerwig and Noah Baumbach, and “Frances Ha” is their origin story. But comparatively little ink is spilled these days on their middle feature (which Baumbach directed), a delightfully funny comedy that turns the tropes of the college coming-of-age movie and the Manic Pixie Dream Girl on their heads. Lola Kirke stars as Tracy, a college freshman new to New York City who gets a whirlwind introduction to the city via her soon-to-be-stepsister Brooke (Gerwig). Gerwig and Baumbach’s wise screenplay delicately dramatizes how Brooke first seems like Tracy’s platonic ideal of the young urban woman, then slowly reveals herself as messy in a multitude of ways. Gerwig’s multilayered performance is one of her best, while Baumbach orchestrates the picture’s shifts from character drama to door-slamming farce with bouncy ease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adalyn Grace
title: Electrifying Love Triangles Make These Y.A. Novels Irresistible
description: Adalyn Grace, the author of the “Belladonna” series and the “All the Stars and Teeth” duology, recommends her favorite young adult novels with heroines torn between competing romantic interests.
content: There’s nothing that gets me turning the pages of a book faster than a love triangle. Maybe I’m a glutton for punishment (most of the time, the romantic interest I root for doesn’t get the girl, and yes, I was Team Jacob), but I always go back for more. I can’t help it. The drama and angst surrounding it all is addictive!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Shepard
title: Martin Scorsese’s Unwise Guys
description: From Travis Bickle to the protagonist of “Killers of the Flower Moon,” the director has excelled at depicting a certain kind of male antihero.
content: If “Men Without Women” seems painfully apt as a title for Ernest Hemingway’s fiction, the equivalent for Martin Scorsese’s work might be “Men Failing Women.” From “Who’s That Knocking at My Door” to “Killers of the Flower Moon,” for more than 50 years, his movies have been a dismal and heartbreaking primer on what not to do when you love someone. His male protagonists continue to fail their significant others even when given multiple chances to reverse that pattern: a paradigm even more fraught if the protagonist is a white dimwit and his wife a long-suffering Osage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Met Announces 2024 Art Commissions, Including Lee Bul, Sculptor of Cyborgs
description: Lee, of South Korea, will transform the facade; Petrit Halilaj of Kosovo, the Roof Garden; and Tong Yang-Tze, the Great Hall with calligraphy.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has selected three international artists for commissions that will showcase contemporary art’s capacity for “earned optimism,” the organizers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The U.S. Charged an Indian Man in a Plot to Kill a Sikh Activist
description: Also, negotiators race to extend the Gaza truce. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Federal prosecutors accused an Indian national today of attempting to kill a Sikh separatist in New York City. The indictment says the plan was linked to the June assassination of a separatist in Canada, allegations that could complicate relations between Washington, Ottawa and New Delhi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Britain Restricts Weighing of Gymnasts in Wake of Abuse
description: Athletes also must be allowed to hydrate regularly when practicing and be permitted visits to the restroom.
content: The weighing of gymnasts will be restricted under new British rules after a report detailed abuse in the sport, particularly of women and girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Benjamin Mueller
title: U.S. Life Expectancy Creeps Up as Covid Deaths Fall
description: But the country’s health has not fully rebounded from the pandemic, according to new data from the C.D.C.
content: Life expectancy in the United States has begun to climb again as the threat of Covid-19 has receded, increasing by more than a year from 2021 to 2022, according to data released on Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Kate Christobek
title: Trump’s Bankers Say His Exaggerated Net Worth Did Not Affect Loans
description: The testimony of witnesses from Deutsche Bank lent support to a central plank of former President Donald Trump’s defense in the civil fraud case against him.
content: Bankers whom Donald J. Trump is accused of defrauding testified at his civil fraud trial this week that they did not rely on his embellished claims of wealth, lending support to the central plank of the former president’s defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: JPMorgan Chief Addresses the E.S.G. Backlash
description: Mr. Dimon has called the Texas laws bad for business, highlighting the work the bank does to fund schools, hospitals and other businesses.
content: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Wednesday that he would now “punch back” over Texas’s 2021 efforts to restrict the state’s business with financial firms that embrace environmental, social and governance policies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fearful of Trump’s Autocratic Ambitions
description: Readers worry about Donald Trump’s plans if elected — or not elected. Also: Pro-Palestinian students; Mideast myths; standards for prosecutors; neoliberalism today.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Frances Sternhagen, Actress Who Thrived in Mature Roles, Dies at 93
description: Her Tony-winning Broadway career included “Driving Miss Daisy,” “On Golden Pond” and “The Heiress.” On TV she had maternal roles in “Cheers” and “Sex and the City.”
content: Frances Sternhagen, the Tony Award-winning actress who played leading roles in stage productions of “Driving Miss Daisy” and “On Golden Pond” as formidable older women when she was so young that she had to wear aging makeup, died on Monday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ocular
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word ocular has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 6 in “Hidden Art: A Rhapsody for the Soul, in 10 City Corners” by Eric V. Copage:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Jonathan Majors, Film Career in the Balance, Faces Trial in Assault Case
description: Few misdemeanor cases go this far, but the actor, a rising Hollywood star before his arrest, wants to salvage his reputation.
content: An actor who was on the precipice of superstardom when Manhattan prosecutors accused him of assaulting his then-girlfriend is set to go on trial Wednesday, seeking to keep his career alive in an unusual proceeding that is expected to attract national attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom, Amy Julia Harris and Jeffery C. Mays
title: New York Claims Progress in Moving Mentally Ill People Off Streets
description: New York City has helped some of the most severely mentally ill homeless people, Mayor Eric Adams said, but he said more needed to be done to reach all those on the streets.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday that New York City had made progress in helping homeless people who are severely mentally ill get connected to treatment and housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Jewish Theatermakers Are in Good Company
description: So many of America’s great plays and musicals have been created and performed by Jews. T’s Holiday issue explores why — and gathers dozens of Jewish actors, writers and directors.
content: We have our editorial ideas meeting every Wednesday at 3 and, at one such meeting in November 2022, the T editor at large Kurt Soller shared an argument: that it’s the stage, rather than the screen or even the pages of a novel, where Jewish life in the United States has found its most vivid and nuanced expression — and why is that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: With an Artist’s Help, Paddington Can Go Anywhere
description: For nearly 1,000 straight days, Jason Chou has inserted Paddington, the anthropomorphized bear, into absurd situations. He has no plans to stop.
content: Paddington is the busiest bear in Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: First Cruise: Preparations for a Smooth Sailing
description: What a first-time passenger needs to know about booking popular excursions, avoiding huge bills for drinks, and how to find your way around on a labyrinthine ship.
content: You’ve picked a ship, booked an itinerary and chosen your cabin, but even with the hardest part done, figuring out the ship’s layout and how to get a spot on a popular outing can be daunting. Here’s how to prepare for a smooth first sailing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Nvidia C.E.O. Is Not Worried About Rising A.I. Industry Competition
description: Jensen Huang said that the chips giant enjoys a decadelong lead over rivals because it didn’t just make chips. It reinvented computers.
content: In the year since OpenAI sparked an artificial intelligence boom with its popular ChatGPT chatbot, start-ups and tech giants have been scrambling to develop semiconductors to power the buzzy technology, hoping to muscle in on Nvidia’s market dominance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Hiba Yazbek
title: In the West Bank, Release of Prisoners Deepens Support for Hamas
description: Some people in the West Bank, where frustration with the Palestinian Authority has been simmering for years, believe Hamas and other armed groups are the only ones they can trust to protect them.
content: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Like Watching Other People Watch Sports?
description: Soccer fans are tuning into watchalongs — streaming parties where they can hear and see everything except the game. Does that sound appealing?
content: Are you a sports fan? If so, what’s your favorite way to experience a game? Attending in person? Watching or listening on a television or radio in the comfort of your own home? Going to a friend’s house to cheer on your team along with other rabid fans?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: What to Know About Congestion Pricing
description: The M.T.A. board regulating congestion pricing has detailed recommendations for the program, including how much drivers should pay.
content: The officials who are overseeing congestion pricing in New York City on Wednesday provided details of their recommendations for how much drivers should pay to enter the busiest part of Manhattan and who should get discounts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: London’s Black Cabs Can Soon Join Uber. But Will They?
description: In 2024, passengers are set to have the option to book black cabs through Uber. After longstanding tensions, a union for drivers said they “have no interest.”
content: Drivers for London’s black cabs will soon be able to offer rides on Uber, the ride-hailing platform announced on Wednesday, in the latest attempt to heal a contentious rift between the company and the city’s signature taxi service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenya’s Leader Lifts His Global Profile. At Home, the Public Fumes.
description: President William Ruto has drawn attention internationally as a climate champion and peace mediator but faces domestic discontent over rising food and fuel prices, and new taxes.
content: He has taken dozens of trips abroad boosting his credentials on climate change, while raising taxes at home. He pledged to send his country’s police to quash gang violence in Haiti, though they stand accused of brutality at home. And he recently hosted an eight-course state dinner for King Charles III, amid skyrocketing food and fuel prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Skipping School
description: Should parents let their children miss school for a vacation?
content: Does your family travel during your time off from school? Have your parents ever let you miss a few days of school, or more, for a trip?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: President Biden’s solidarity with Israel.
content: President Biden is facing deep anger over his solidarity with Israel among his supporters and even from some staff members, particularly those with Arab or Muslim backgrounds, who have said they feel disenchanted with the president. And for many in the Arab community, his words and actions after the Oct. 7 attacks have left them feeling like an afterthought in the war between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Casey Likes of ‘Back to the Future,’ Is on a Roll
description: At 21, he already has two Broadway leads under his belt. On Thursdays, he sheds Marty McFly’s signature vest for a bowling shirt.
content: “I either suck or I’m awesome,” Casey Likes said as he entered Frames, a snazzy bowling alley tucked into a corner of the Port Authority Bus Terminal. “There is no in-between.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Is Shoplifting Really Surging?
description: Claims that the U.S. is in the middle of a retail theft wave are exaggerated.
content: Is the U.S. in the middle of a shoplifting wave? Target and other retail chains have warned of widespread theft. News outlets have amplified the story. On social media, people have posted videos of thieves looting stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Horti
title: A Video Game That Doubles as a World War I History Lesson
description: Last Train Home tells an overlooked story of the Czechoslovak Legion’s evacuation across Russia in the embers of the Great War.
content: When the video game producer Petr Kolar and his future colleagues made a research trip to the Legiovlak, a replica World War I-era train that chugs around the Czech Republic, he noted the pristine Czechoslovak Legion uniforms worn by the museum guides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and Kelley Manley
title: Criminal Trial of Paramedics Opens in the Death of Elijah McClain
description: The third and final trial over Mr. McClain’s 2019 death will examine the role of the medics who responded while the young Black man was in police custody.
content: The trial of two paramedics charged in the death of Elijah McClain began on Wednesday with prosecutors contending that the way the two men acted during a police encounter with Mr. McClain made them criminally responsible for his death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: French Court Clears Justice Minister of Abuse of Power
description: Éric Dupond-Moretti was charged with using his position as a weapon to order investigations into four magistrates he had recently clashed with.
content: The government of President Emmanuel Macron of France dodged a blow on Wednesday when a special court ruled that the justice minister was not guilty of using his position to settle scores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Fears Grow Over Fate of Bibas Family in Gaza
description: Hamas’s armed wing said a mother and her two young children had been killed in Israeli airstrikes. Israel’s military said it was assessing the claim.
content: Concern for members of the Bibas family — a mother and her two young children who have become symbols of the hostages held in Gaza — deepened on Wednesday afternoon when Hamas’s armed wing, the Al Qassam Brigades, claimed the three had been killed in Israeli airstrikes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Rosalynn Carter’s Life in Photos
description: She rose to become the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt. Yet her life began and ended dozens of miles from any interstate highway or even a stoplight.
content: Rosalynn Carter, who died on Nov. 19 at the age of 96, was a bridge — between generations, between the quiet simplicity of small-town life and the chaotic arenas of national and international politics, between competing notions of a woman’s place in the home and in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Federal Law Requires a Choice: Marijuana or a Gun?
description: Legal challenges are pending across the country against a federal law that prevents medical marijuana users from buying or owning firearms.
content: For Vera Cooper, the time had come to buy a gun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Arizona Officials Charged With Conspiring to Delay Election Results
description: An indictment accuses two Cochise County supervisors of interfering with the state canvass of votes. The county has been a hotbed of election conspiracy theories.
content: Two Republican county supervisors in Arizona were indicted Wednesday on felony charges related to their attempts to delay the certification of 2022 election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: E.U. Court Rules Public Offices Can Ban Religious Symbols
description: The decision came after a woman in Belgium was barred from wearing a hijab in the office.
content: Workers can be barred from wearing religious garb, such as head scarves, in the offices of public administrations, a European Union court ruled on Tuesday, tapping into a charged debate in Europe about expressions of faith in public institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy
title: Israeli Forces Kill 4 in West Bank, Palestinian Officials Say
description: Two children, ages 8 and 15, and two members of armed groups were killed in a raid in Jenin, according to the Palestinian health ministry and a camp official.
content: Two children were shot dead by Israeli soldiers during a raid in the city of Jenin in the northern West Bank, on Wednesday, the Palestinian health ministry and a local official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Scottish Country Music Venue Ends Display of Confederate Flag
description: The flag, and efforts to ban it, had caused a rift among members of the Grand Ole Opry in Glasgow.
content: A country and western music venue in Scotland, nearly 4,000 miles and 150 years removed from the Civil War, voted this week to end its controversial display of the Confederate flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Paris, 1919: History’s Slingshot
description: What happened in early 20th century Europe still propels much of modern politics, including the conflict in Gaza and Israel.
content: It feels urgent to revisit the events of early 20th century Europe right now. Reading about that era feels like watching someone draw back the slingshot whose energy still propels much of modern politics, including the conflict in Gaza and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Juzwiak
title: Who Can Take a Joke? Everyone.
description: The authors of “Comedy Book” and “Outrageous” argue that culture-war worries about what’s a laughing matter have been overplayed.
content: Did you hear the one about cancel culture?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Brenda Lee, a Queen of Christmas and So Much More
description: “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree” has been a holiday staple for 65 years. But Lee, who recorded it at 13, has never rested on her laurels.
content: On a balmy day 65 years ago, a 13-year-old girl walked into a Nashville recording studio decorated with colored lights, garlands and a Christmas tree, the air conditioning cranked up to approximate a late-December chill. Members of the A Team, the session musicians who churned out hits for everyone in town, gamely donned Santa hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Federal Civil Rights Investigation Opened Into Antisemitism at Harvard
description: There are now federal investigations into complaints of discrimination at several colleges.
content: The Office for Civil Rights of the U.S. Education Department has opened an investigation into allegations of antisemitism at Harvard University, where the campus, like many others, has been roiled by demonstrations and confrontations between pro-Israel and pro-Palestinian students in the weeks since the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 16 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in December
description: We rounded up the best titles leaving the streaming service for U.S. subscribers. That includes Oscar winners, comedies, horror and four ‘Jaws’ films.
content: The end of the year means plenty of expiring licenses on Netflix, so December’s list of movies exiting the service is bulkier than usual — and more prestigious, including two Oscar winners for best picture, two massively popular franchises and recent favorites of horror, comedy and family entertainment. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Rare Giant Rat Is Photographed Alive for First Time
description: The people who live on the island of Vangunu were adamant that the critically endangered species still existed. They helped researchers prove that they were right.
content: For years, the Indigenous people on Vangunu, one of the Solomon Islands, had insisted a critically endangered giant rat that could chew through coconuts still lived among the trees of the forest, though its numbers had dwindled as loggers destroyed its habitat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By H. Claire Brown
title: The Chicken Tycoons vs. the Antitrust Hawks
description: As part of a broader campaign against anticompetitive practices, the Biden administration has taken on the chicken industry. Why have the results been so paltry?
content: At Kentucky Fried Chicken, sales tend to peak at the same time every year: Mother’s Day. This has been the case since the 1960s, when the chain began to experiment with TV advertising. In a spot from that era, a man in an office answers a phone call from an anonymous male narrator who asks, “Sir, do you have any idea what your wife has to do to run your house?” Cut to a sped-up montage of an impeccably dressed 30-something as she dusts, irons, vacuums and balances the checkbook. Newly enlightened, the husband shows his appreciation by stopping at Kentucky Fried Chicken on his way home. Cut to a close-up of a happy wife biting into a drumstick. “Colonel Sanders fixes Sunday dinner seven days a week, and it’s finger-lickin’ good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: After Tragedy, a Failed System in New York Is Revealed
description: Two Times reporters spent more than a year examining how breakdowns of New York City’s social safety net preceded some acts of violence by homeless and mentally ill people.
content: Amy Julia Harris and Jan Ransom’s recent New York Times investigation started over a year ago, after a tragedy. Michelle Go, a 40-year-old financial consultant, was standing on a subway platform in January 2022 when a 61-year-old man shoved her in front of a moving train. Ms. Go was killed, rattling New Yorkers. Ms. Harris and Ms. Ransom, who cover New York City for The Times, wanted to understand where the system had failed Ms. Go and her assailant, who was homeless and mentally ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Review: This ‘House of Bernarda Alba’ Is on Fire
description: Rebecca Frecknall, whose “Cabaret” is heading to Broadway, steers Federico García Lorca’s play to its tragic finish with genuinely shocking force.
content: The ground is breathing fire, we’re told, in “The House of Bernarda Alba,” the Spanish classic by Federico García Lorca that opened Tuesday at the National Theater in London in a ferocious new version by Alice Birch. The show runs through Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Margaret Lyons
title: Best TV Shows of 2023
description: Series like “The Bear,” “Beef,” “Happy Valley,” “Reservation Dogs” and “Succession” dazzled in a year when much of the TV business was in disarray.
content: TV in 2023 was like synchronized swimming. Below the surface, there was roiling and churn. The writers’ and actors’ strikes wiped out much of the production year. The hangover from the corporate binge on streaming platforms led to cancellations and cutbacks. A number of hall-of-fame series left the air, with no clear plan of, as it were, succession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Jamie Dimon Urges Donors, Even Democrats, to ‘Help Nikki Haley’
description: The JPMorgan Chase C.E.O.’s show of support for Ms. Haley came on the same day that a new super PAC set out to try to draw independent voters to her candidacy.
content: The chief executive of Wall Street’s largest bank threw his support behind Nikki Haley on Wednesday, just as a group of entrepreneurs confirmed that they were forming a super PAC to try to draw independent voters to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Some in Netanyahu’s Government Pressure Him to Reject Longer Cease-Fire
description: “Stopping the war = breaking apart the government,” said Itamar Ben-Gvir, Israel’s far-right national security minister, who threatened to leave the governing coalition.
content: As international pressure grows to extend a temporary cease-fire with Hamas, some right-wing members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government are threatening to bring it down if he does not resume fighting in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Anjali Huynh
title: Could Abortion Rights Rescue Red-State Democrats in the Senate?
description: Senator Sherrod Brown is betting that the issue will aid his re-election bid in Ohio, which recently upheld abortion rights. Allies of Senator Jon Tester of Montana are also hoping it helps.
content: In the opening minutes of a debate during Sherrod Brown’s successful 2006 campaign for Senate, the Republican incumbent attacked him over “partial-birth abortion,” a phrase often weaponized by conservatives at the time to paint Democrats as somewhere between immoral and murderous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Understanding the True Nature of the Hamas-Israel War
description: It’s actually three wars, and there’s one keystone that we have to get right.
content: The reason the Hamas-Israel war can be hard for outsiders to understand is that three wars are going on at the same time: a war between Israeli Jews and the Palestinians exacerbated by a terrorist group, a war within Israeli and Palestinian societies over the future and a war between Iran and its proxies and America and its allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Before the DeSantis-Newsom Debate, Let’s Look at Their Economic Records
description: Florida and California both have strengths to boast about, but the data reveals weaknesses, too.
content: I’ll be glued to the TV on Thursday for the debate between Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Fox News. (Not a plug.) It will pit a conservative Republican against a liberal Democrat, a one-time outfielder for Yale against a one-time pitcher for Santa Clara University, a fighter against another fighter. As Fox’s Sean Hannity told The Times, DeSantis and Newsom are “two very smart, well-educated, highly opinionated, philosophically different governors” who are “diametrically opposed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany’s Much-Vaunted Strategic Pivot Stalls
description: In the days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz promised to revitalize Germany’s military. Nearly two years on, major change has yet to be felt.
content: Just days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed to revitalize a German military that had fallen into disrepair since the end of the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Rosalynn Carter Returns for a Final Time to the Place She Found Most Comfort
description: A simple red brick church where Mrs. Carter had worshiped for decades was filled on Wednesday with the people who had known her best.
content: To them, she was more than a first lady.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Will Reid, Alex Stern, Carlos Prieto, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Ending Roe Was Supposed to Reduce Abortions. It Didn’t.
description: States that banned abortion after the Dobbs decision saw more births. But nationwide, terminations rose slightly.
content: From the moment that Roe v. Wade was overturned, the question was just how much the change would reduce abortions across the United States. Now, more than a year later, the numbers are in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: How to Actually Work Out With Your Kids
description: It’s tough to balance child care and regular exercise, but there are ways to make real fitness gains alongside your kids.
content: For parents of young kids, it can be hard to prioritize exercise. Children need things — a snack, a ride, a person to explain fractions — and usually just as you’re lacing up your running shoes or laying out the yoga mat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Aunt of 4-Year-Old Israeli Hostage Talks About Her Time in Captivity
description: Avigail Idan shared one piece of pita bread per day with four others, and did not have a shower or bath during her 50 days in captivity, her aunt said.
content: An aunt of Avigail Idan, the girl who was taken hostage by Hamas after she saw her parents brutally killed and who turned 4 a few days before being released, says that her niece shared one piece of pita bread per day with four others, and did not have a shower or bath during her 50 days in captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno
title: At Least One Dead as U.S. Osprey Crashes in Japan With 8 Onboard
description: The incident comes three months after three Marines died in an Osprey crash in Australia.
content: A U.S. military aircraft crashed near a small island off the coast of southern Japan on Wednesday with eight people onboard, the U.S. Air Force said. Japan’s Coast Guard said that at least one of those onboard had been confirmed dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: With Charlie Munger’s Death, Berkshire Loses a Custodian of Its Culture
description: Mr. Munger’s death won’t affect the day-to-day operations of the conglomerate, but shareholders will miss his imprint on the company’s ethos.
content: Shares of Berkshire Hathaway barely budged on Wednesday, a day after its vice chairman, Charlie Munger, died, reflecting the view among shareholders that Mr. Munger’s absence on the conglomerate’s day to day would have little impact on its future, even as they mourned the loss of the man who helped shape Berkshire’s culture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Can Rap Bridge Its Generation Gap?
description: Is it possible for rappers to age gracefully? Where are the new stars? A discussion on the state of the genre and where it may be heading.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Announces Drive to Organize Nonunion Plants
description: The United Automobile Workers’ effort, with a long-elusive goal, follows its success in securing big raises in contracts with the Detroit automakers.
content: The United Automobile Workers union announced Wednesday that it was undertaking an ambitious drive to organize plants owned by more than a dozen nonunion automakers, including Tesla and several foreign companies — a goal that has long eluded it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Gaza Mediators, Eye on Long Term, Press for Short Truce Extension
description: Officials from Qatar, Egypt and the U.S. hope that a succession of pauses will pave the way toward a larger goal: bringing the war to a close.
content: Top officials from Qatar, Egypt and the United States pushed on Wednesday to lock in another temporary extension of the cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, seeing it as the best way to ease the embattled territory’s humanitarian crisis, secure the release of more Israeli hostages and slow the war’s escalating death toll for at least a little longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: For Women ‘Art Monsters,’ Both Beauty and Excess Are Key
description: The new book by Lauren Elkin examines artists who’ve defied conventions and expectations, including Carolee Schneemann, Eva Hesse and Kara Walker.
content: When the essayist Lauren Elkin first encountered the phrase that would provide the striking title for her new book, the moment felt to her like a “thunderbolt.” She was reading Jenny Offill’s novel “Dept. of Speculation” (2014), whose narrator had planned never to marry because she “was going to be an art monster instead.” A man could marry and be an art monster; a woman could not. An art monster doesn’t tend to the mundane demands of daily life, whether her own or others’. She is relentless, selfish, single-minded. To create, she must destroy — or, at the very least, choose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Franklin-Wallis
title: I’m Appalled by What I Learned About Recycling. But We Can Fix It.
description: In the short term, recycling might be the best option we have against our growing waste crisis.
content: It happened again the other night: Washing up after dinner, I went to throw out a packet of just-eaten instant tortellini and was flummoxed. It was plastic, sure. But what kind? There was no resin code or recycling symbol on the package. Nothing on the label, either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: $15 Tolls Likely for Nation’s First Congestion Pricing Program
description: New York wants to discourage drivers from contributing to some of the world’s heaviest traffic. After decades of delays, the plan is nearly a reality.
content: The first congestion pricing program in the United States is taking final shape in New York City, and it appears likely that most drivers will have to pay $15 to enter some of the busiest streets in Manhattan as soon as next spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Jacey Fortin
title: Americans Glimpse Jimmy Carter’s Frailty and His Resolve
description: “Come hell or high water, Jimmy Carter was going to use his inner resources to be there,” the presidential historian Douglas Brinkley said of Mr. Carter’s emerging from hospice care for his wife’s memorial service.
content: His face was pale and gaunt, his legs were wrapped in a blanket, and his eyes never seemed to make contact with the family members huddled around him. But on Tuesday, Jimmy Carter was there, in the front row of a church in Atlanta, just a few feet from the coffin holding Rosalynn Carter, his wife of 77 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s the Lineup for the 2023 DealBook Summit, and When to Watch
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan, and Elon Musk are among those being interviewed Wednesday by The Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin.
content: The hype and hope driving artificial intelligence, the rise of antisemitism since Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack on Israel, inflation, dysfunction in Washington and the streaming wars — these topics and more will be addressed at the 2023 DealBook Summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: A U.S.-Iranian Miscalculation Could Lead to a Larger War, Officials Say
description: U.S. forces and militias backed by Iran have launched tit-for-tat attacks, fueling concerns as Israeli forces have also clashed with Iranian-backed groups.
content: Neither Washington nor Tehran wants the conflict in the Gaza Strip to trigger a wider war in the region, officials in both capitals say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Thomas Fuller and Talya Minsberg
title: Hamas Releases 12 More Hostages as Nations’ Spy Chiefs Go to Qatar for Talks
description: Mediators hope the current model of a daily cease-fire with the release of Israeli captives in exchange for freeing Palestinian prisoners would create the conditions for longer-term discussions.
content: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chuck Schumer
title: Chuck Schumer: What American Jews Fear Most
description: Having concerns about Israel’s policies is no excuse for attacking Jews simply for being Jews.
content: Fifty-three days ago, citizens of Israel suffered a horrendous attack orchestrated and executed by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Harris to Stand In for Biden at U.N. Climate Conference
description: The president attended the annual conference in 2021 and 2022, but officials say this year he is preoccupied with the wars in the Middle East and in Ukraine.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will attend the annual United Nations climate summit in Dubai on Friday and Saturday, standing in for President Biden, who will skip the event for the first time since taking office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Elon Musk, Kamala Harris, Isaac Herzog: Takeaways from the 2023 DealBook Summit
description: The interviews included a defiant Mr. Musk on an advertiser boycott at X, the vice president on the Biden administration’s challenges reaching voters, and the Israeli president on hostages in Gaza.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris, President Isaac Herzog of Israel, Elon Musk and other leaders in business and politics spoke on everything from artificial intelligence, economic tensions between the United States and China, and Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel at the annual DealBook Summit in New York on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Has No Labels Become a Stalking Horse for Trump?
description: Whatever its intentions, there is a reason the organization is supported by major Republican donors like Harlan Crow.
content: No Labels, a Washington-based organization run by political and corporate insiders, finds itself in an awkward situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The National Christmas Tree Fell Over. Insert Metaphor Here.
description: Does it symbolize President Biden’s economic policies, or the pressures of the season?
content: In a bold affront to the holiday season, the National Christmas Tree eschewed its festive duties and fell over on Tuesday afternoon, alarming federal park workers and temporarily throwing the plans for the national tree-lighting ceremony into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Emma Stone and Yorgos Lanthimos Have Nothing and Everything in Common
description: “I’m a girl from Arizona and he’s a guy from Athens. I don’t know how this worked,” she says. Their latest project, “Poor Things,” may be Oscar-bound.
content: It’s one thing to cry while performing. Emma Stone can do that. What she doesn’t want to do, and what she found herself doing anyway, is to cry in the middle of an interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Harris Defends Biden’s Policies, but Says More Work Is Needed to Reach Voters
description: The vice president, speaking at The Times’s DealBook Summit, said record-low unemployment and stable wages were not enough to “connect” with struggling Americans.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Wednesday that the Biden administration had done more in the past two years to wrangle rising inflation “than most advanced economies,” but admitted that more needed to be done to convince a deeply pessimistic public that the president’s policies had been beneficial to Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: For Haley, Rise in Polls Feeds Voter Enthusiasm on Trail
description: The crowds are her biggest yet, and voters are warming up to her candidacy, but Nikki Haley still faces a daunting task in taking down the front-runner, Donald Trump.
content: In a packed opera house on Tuesday night in Derry, N.H., Hannah Kesselring had a pressing question for Nikki Haley, one that many voters in the room appear to have been considering as Ms. Haley has climbed in the 2024 Republican presidential contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: How Jewish People Built the American Theater
description: It’s a history “based on the necessity of opening up and looking beyond, instead of suffocating in, the small space of the self — not only to avoid being pigeonholed but also to exercise the muscle of sympathy.”
content: It’s a history “based on the necessity of opening up and looking beyond, instead of suffocating in, the small space of the self — not only to avoid being pigeonholed but also to exercise the muscle of sympathy.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. v. Gupta Indictment

title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘63 Up’ and More
description: I am a national correspondent on religion, faith and values. Here are five things I'm enjoying right now.
content: I am a national correspondent on religion, faith and values. Here are five things I'm enjoying right now.

title: Herzog Says Israel Is Fighting on Behalf of the ‘Free World’
description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel said that in order “to change the equation” in the Middle East, Israel has to “uproot” Hamas.

title: Gazans Wait in Long Lines for Supplies During Brief Cease-Fire
description: People are stocking up on basic necessities like water and fuel during the temporary window of relief from the violence.
content: People are stocking up on basic necessities like water and fuel during the temporary window of relief from the violence.

title: David Zaslav Defends Unpopular Decisions at Warner Bros. Discovery
description: David Zaslav, chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery, said that a series of cuts, including scrapping the “Batgirl” movie and firing close friends, were necessary business decisions.
content: David Zaslav, chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery, said that a series of cuts, including scrapping the “Batgirl” movie and firing close friends, were necessary business decisions.

title: Taiwanese President Says China Is Unlikely to Invade at This Time
description: Tsai Ing-wen, the president of Taiwan, said internal economic and political challenges in China, as well as international pressure, has made a major invasion by China unlikely.
content: Tsai Ing-wen, the president of Taiwan, said internal economic and political challenges in China, as well as international pressure, has made a major invasion by China unlikely.

title: Shonda Rhimes Says She Doesn’t Watch Television or Track Ratings
description: Shonda Rhimes, the TV producer and screenwriter behind hit shows such as “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Bridgerton,” shared that she only makes shows that she’s “obsessed with.”
content: Shonda Rhimes, the TV producer and screenwriter behind hit shows such as “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Bridgerton,” shared that she only makes shows that she’s “obsessed with.”

title: Harris Not Worried About Biden Trailing Trump in Key Polls
description: Vice President Kamala Harris pointed to victories by Democrats in recent elections when asked about former President Donald J. Trump beating the Biden-Harris ticket in recent polls.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris pointed to victories by Democrats in recent elections when asked about former President Donald J. Trump beating the Biden-Harris ticket in recent polls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: McCarthy Says He Is Undecided on Whether to Seek Re-Election
description: Representative Kevin McCarthy of California has filed re-election paperwork, but has until Dec. 8 to make a final decision on if he will run.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy of California has filed re-election paperwork, but has until Dec. 8 to make a final decision on if he will run.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Disney C.E.O. Denies Plan to Sell TV Business
description: Bob Iger, the chief executive of Disney, said the company is constantly evaluating its assets and their value.
content: Bob Iger, the chief executive of Disney, said the company is constantly evaluating its assets and their value.

title: JP Morgan Will ‘Punch Back’ on Texas’ Efforts to Limit Its Business
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JP Morgan Chase, said that there would be “consequences” for the state’s attempts to restrict business with banks that embrace environmental, social and governance policies.
content: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JP Morgan Chase, said that there would be “consequences” for the state’s attempts to restrict business with banks that embrace environmental, social and governance policies.

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. Will Take Years to Reach Chip Independence, Nvidia C.E.O. Says
description: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, said that he believed the United States was at least a decade away from breaking its dependence on chips created overseas.
content: Jensen Huang, the chief executive of Nvidia, said that he believed the United States was at least a decade away from breaking its dependence on chips created overseas.
